abstract: AT&T has fired a new shot in the Wi-Fi wars with Thursday’s $275 million acquisition of Wayport, a privately held provider of wireless Internet hotspots. The all-cash deal increases AT&T’s wireless Internet footprint as it prepares to compete with a consortium of companies led by Sprint Nextel that are developing a faster alternative to the wireless network currently used by mobile phone companies.
lead_paragraph: AT&T has fired a new shot in the Wi-Fi wars with Thursday’s $275 million acquisition of Wayport, a privately held provider of wireless Internet hotspots. The all-cash deal increases AT&T’s wireless Internet footprint as it prepares to compete with a consortium of companies led by Sprint Nextel that are developing a faster alternative to the wireless network currently used by mobile phone companies.
